In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

```julia
function wrap_string(text::String, text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(text)
    lines = []

    for word in words
        if length(word) + sum(length(line) for line in lines)) > text_width
            push!(lines, word)
        else
            if !isempty(lines) && endswith(last(lines), "-"))
                last(lines) = last(lines)[1:end-2] * " " * word
            else
                push!(lines, join(words[1:i], " ")) *
                    (i < length(words) ? "â€”\n" : "")
                i += 1
            end
        end
    end

    return join(lines, "\n")
end
```

Here's an example usage:

```julia
text = "In programming, a function is a block of code that performs a specific task. Functions are incredibly useful for reusing code and organizing complex programs."
wrapped_text = wrap_string(text)
println(wrapped_text)
```

This will output the wrapped text with line breaks to maintain the `text_width` limit.
